title: 109_s3583
content: REGULATION OF PAYROLL TAX DEPOSIT AGENTS: An amendment to Chapter 77 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 7529, focusing on payroll tax deposit agents. The Secretary will establish a system for registration and renewal of payroll tax deposit agents, with a fee not exceeding $100 and the option to submit a bond. The system for registration and renewal of payroll tax deposit agents includes a registration fee, bond submission option, disclosure requirements, and direct employer notification. The system for registration and renewal of payroll tax deposit agents includes requirements for disclosures, direct employer notification, and penalties for unregistered agents. The system for registration and renewal of payroll tax deposit agents includes requirements for disclosures, direct employer notification, and penalties for unregistered agents. A payroll tax deposit agent is defined as any person providing payroll processing or tax services. Penalties may be imposed for noncompliance, including fines up to $10,000 for each 90 days of noncompliance. Penalties may be imposed on payroll tax deposit agents for noncompliance, with fines up to $10,000 for each 90 days of noncompliance. A payroll tax deposit agent is defined as a person providing payroll processing or tax services to employers. A payroll tax deposit agent is a person who provides payroll processing or tax services to employers and has the authority to access employer funds for making employment tax deposits. This term excludes individuals who only transfer funds without the authority to impound them for this purpose. The definition of employment tax includes unemployment insurance. The term "employment tax" includes unemployment insurance contributions. A payroll tax deposit agent must submit a bond of $50,000 to $500,000 determined for each deposit. The term "employment tax" includes unemployment insurance contributions. A payroll tax deposit agent can elect to submit a bond of $50,000 to $500,000, determined for each agent under regulations prescribed by the Secretary. The bond or security must be in a form with surety as prescribed by regulations. Annual audits for payroll tax deposit agents who elect to submit to them shall be conducted by an independent third party based on principles determined by the Secretary, including a focus on the agent's escrow account. Annual audits for payroll tax deposit agents who choose to undergo them will be conducted by an independent third party. The audit will focus on ensuring that the agent's escrow account is balanced yearly to the total of quarterly reconciliation statements, that escrow account funds are not mixed with operating funds, and that there is no evidence of misuse of funds. The escrow account of the payroll tax deposit agent is balanced yearly to the quarterly reconciliation statements. Funds are not commingled with operating funds, and there is no evidence of misuse. Receipt evidence shows that required employment taxes are paid to the government. The Secretary requires payroll tax deposit agents to disclose clients' liability for Federal and State employment taxes, regardless of any contractual relationship. Agents must also provide evidence of paying required employment taxes to the government. The Secretary mandates payroll tax deposit agents to inform clients about their responsibility for Federal and State employment taxes, regardless of any contract. Clients must be provided with ways to verify tax deposits made by the agent. The Secretary requires payroll tax deposit agents to provide clients with information on verifying tax deposits and other necessary details for selecting and using agents. Only registered persons can make Federal tax deposits on behalf of an employer. The Secretary mandates payroll tax deposit agents to provide essential information to assist employers in selecting and using agents. Only registered individuals can make Federal tax deposits, file tax returns, and access confidential tax information on behalf of employers. Regulations will be prescribed to implement these provisions. The Secretary requires payroll tax deposit agents to sign and file Federal employment tax returns and have access to confidential tax information. Regulations will be prescribed to enforce these provisions. Additionally, any payroll tax deposit agent who fails to collect or pay over tax will be subject to penalties under Section 6672(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment to Section 6672(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes payroll tax deposit agents as individuals subject to penalties for failure to collect and pay over tax or attempt to evade or defeat tax. This does not affect the interpretation of the existing section. The amendment made by paragraph (1) does not create any inference with the interpretation of section 6672 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 77. The amendments regarding payroll tax deposit agents will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with penalties applying to failures occurring after that date.
